column4: We visited here this week, choosing to walk up the seven stories of ramps from exhibit to exhibit. The architecture, slendiferous. The displays: mind stimulating and something for everyone in different cultures and age groups. As a retired educator, I was quite surprised and delighted by how much I learned. The special exhibit on Canada 150 years old was wonderful.

This museum is completely devoted to catastrophes brought upon by the empires and does not feature any other tribal wars or conflicts from other nationalities. Very expensive tickets and not worth the trip. Its great if you are a student doing a project, but I wouldn't put it on a must see list in Winnipeg - you can do your...

Great exhibits, you can spend hours exploring. We went on a corporate event was only able to see a couple of exhibits. The tower was closed which is a shame would have love to have gone up for the view at sunset. Lots to learn and discover, the material is quite heavy but important non the less. Overall a must...

much of the suffering portrayed there was warped with a definite socialist twist on the Worlds injustices. I was a little hesitant to visit, but tagged along with some others we were traveling with and I am so glad I did. The architecture alone is worth going for. We went two hours before closing and saw every floor, but could have spent much more time looking at the exhibits. There was so much to learn about Canadian...
Give yourself lots of time to tour the whole building. Lots of reading if your into historical data . The kids didn't get as much out of it but hopefully they will go back when there are older.
Four hours was not enough time to experience all of the exhibits. So many stories under one roof. Looking forward to a followup visit.

Didn't know what to expect when we went there. Hard to believe that we as a people can do that to so many cultures. Really opened my eyes and was very well presented. I would highly recommend it for all ages above early teen.
Wonderful exhibits but there is a great deal of walking. The restaurant had an eclectic menu and well presented. A must see museum when in Winnipeg.

First time to the museum but probably won't be the last. Very large interior but expect a fair amount of walking( you can use elevators though). Very technologically-oriented with many inter-active stations.Particularly informative and heart-wrenching exhibit on the Holocaust and many more exhibits which capture the essence of human rights from a global perspective.

column4: Covers a large spectrum of human rights, some specific to Canada but most international. Everything from the Holocaust to modern day bullying. Much to take in, you could return again and again. Well worth a half day visit

Great architecture. Second visit to the museum. There is a lot to see and is an interesting walk through the facility. Found many interesting exhibits and some have an interactive component that draws you in to learn more. The Canadian Museum of Human Rights is a tremendous addition to Winnipeg and well worth the time to visit.

I was amazed by the spectacular architecture of the building and all the exhibits. Be prepared to spend a considerable amount of time as there is so much to see in this museum. There is also a restaurant and a gift shop on site.

I was in awe of this wonderful museum and the thought and dedication that went into it. Not only was the building spectacular but the guided tour of the displays were heart wrenching and beautiful. This truly touched me emotionally. Bring tissues . Very impressive. Very lucky to have this legacy in my home city.

I was in town for work and we had a "rain" day. So instead of sitting around the hotel I decided to check out this museum that some of the locals recommended. Not what I expected, but much more! I think everyone should see this! Not just for the message, the powerful images, but the architectural triumph!

I went to the museum really not knowing what to expect . I am not a museum person or so I thought. But this museum grabbed my attention right away with a huge interactive screen showing the world time line of human rights. The architecture of the building alone captivated my attention. The story of the aboriginal people is beautifully...
Awesome architecture!If you care about other people or the human race in general, this is the place to be

Very good attraction and very informative about human rights. There are a lot of exhibits that will appeal to all ages, some even hands-on. I went there on a school field trip and it helped supplement what I already knew about human rights and their abuses both around the world and in Canada.

There is so much to see at the museum for human rights that it is virtually impossible to see it all in one visit or afternoon. Take you time and read the stories of hardship and perseverance.An extraordinary display of heart wrenching turmoil. Well worth the time you will spend.The staff is fantastic

I've now twice visited the CMHR. Each visit was unique, and I came away with a renewed perspective and a deeper reverence for those who suffered injustices in our Canadian society (and beyond). I very much appreciate their treatment of indigenous culture; highlighting some things that many other exhibits just gloss over. In a way, however, the CMHR leadership do...

The Building itself is worth the admission price. The architecture is unique and the view from near the top spectacular. If you are looking for exhibits of furniture and artifacts from various times and places (like the Museum of Man and Nature). you will bedisappointed. However if you want to know about Human Rights issues over time in Canada, you...

A beautiful and meaningful experience as you move from floor to floor. Phone for a booking with a guide for your first visit...a must to understanding all the symbolism. This is a visit not to be missed in Winnipeg.

The museum is off to a good start but really needs more looping videos that dramatize the stories of human rights stories. I'd like to see more displays on the human rights stories of The Irish, Polish,Ukrainian and Aboriginal people such as the Holodomor, the oppression of the Irish by the Brits and Scots, the German mistreatment of the Poles...

The CMHR is a world class experience. The museum needs six visits to take it all in and give it the respect it deserves. It's truly amazing...the Bistro is just lovely, sharing tastes from all over. The boutique is so worth a visit each and every time as new items arrive all the time. The women's fair trade show last...

Recently took a tour of the canadian rights museum in winnipeg ,manitoba. From the minute you walk in you are greeted with pleasant and knowlegable staff willing to guide you along the unsual displays on each floor. Make sure you have plenty of time to be able to read and view many displays in each area. The video on the...
A great building design that reflects how different we all are and yet how we can all co-exist. Great interactive exhibits that involve the entire family. A very neat venue for a wedding.
So awesome! A must in Winnipeg! Very reasonable prizes. Great exhibits. Things for the entire family to see and read.

In Winnipeg you will be found one the best and awesome museum in Canada. You have to spend 3 hours inside the museum. Don't ever jump into another feature because you will miss the beautiful and awesome view of every each corner. It's a friend and cozy inside you will be amaze their add that attributes to all of us....

The menu is very worldly. One photo is roasted chickpeas and popcorn! You don't find that everyday.Some things on the menu I have never heard of like jackfruit, golden-eye Daphine dumpling, carrot fries, maple-spiced roasted chickpeas, Vita egg, and grana padano.We split the pulled pork sandwich with carrot fries. See picture of half sandwich. Carrot fries are yummy...

One of the most amazing buildings I've ever been in.. the alabaster is breath taking. The garden of reflection is such a great idea, by the time you reach this area you'll need some time to just process everything you just saw.So informative, a truly humbling experience that stirs a lot of emotion.

The attractions take a lot of time to read. This is an educational tour. Visitors will need to take their time to view things. The design of the building is unique and attractive. Especially loved how bright things were in the plant room.

The museum does a great job of conveying important human rights issues and can be a great stepping point for continued discussions and learning, but it is hard to ensure you see everything and the circular galleries sometimes cause you to miss information or displays. Overall though, an enormous asset and a fabulous way to help spread awareness of critical...

I highly recommend the Human Rights museum. I was recommended staying here for three hours. I thought I would have possibly got bored after that amount of time, however three hours flew by. The museum isn't very kid friendly. I'm glad I had a sitter so I could take my time and learn about so many human rights infractions I...

Ordinarily I am not big on museums. I start off keen and get bored quickly. This was not the case here. There were a variety of multimedia and interactive displays which showed the topic in a well rounded and inclusive way without being too preachy. That was another worry of mine, pre-visit - that it would be depressing and demoralizing,...

I explored the Canadian Museum for Human Rights on a guided tour and it was so good that I decided to walk through the entire museum again on my own! Our tour guide was very knowledgeable about the pieces in the museum and contributed a wealth of interesting facts and information during our tour. There is so much to see...

From the moment you walk in you will be amazed! The building itself is something else. As you walk along each walkway from one level to the next, the sides of the walkways are all alabaster with lighting behind the stone that gives a beautiful glow. On Saturdays they give a special tour of the building itself explaining all of...

Plan to spend at least a couple of hours visiting this museum. Easy parking in the lot across the street. Fairly expensive admission fee. The best thing about the museum is the building architecture, it is fantastic. The reflection gardens with waterfalls is a nice area to take a beak from the reading-heavy displays.Some of the interactive units were...

Our Canadian Museum of Human Rights is a must see. The exhibits change frequently, and the interactive sections are very good. So much to see, that I recommend that it may take you two days to absorb it all ..

Beautiful well throughout museum! Ticket is good for the entire day and the displays can take a bit of an emotional toll on you - you can take a break and go outside for a walk, enjoy the Forks market and then return. I prefer to start at the bottom and work my way to the top as you become...

Canadians are really leading by example with this incredible national museum. They do a great job tastefully reminding us of past transgressions against humanity and more importantly reminding us that our actions matter and ALL HUMANITY MATTERS. The symbolism of the architecture all the way to providing a contemplation garden and all the attention to detail is inspiring and set...

Beautiful architecture for an important collection of stories along with some artefacts. Nice to learn about human rights issues from across Canada and the greater global community. Hope that as the museum grows they can add more specifically regarding Manitoba.

We were recommended to start at the top and walk down. That was good advice. Beautiful views and interesting history and present issues from around the world.There are great insights into human err and accomplishments worth learning.Take your kids and teens. Great rainy or cold day activity.

I loved my trip to the Museum and I would recommend taking the tour, but then go back and see the parts that you are interested in after. You could easily spend 5+ hours here if you are interested in human rights at all. The tour was about 2 hrs.

I've lived in Winnipeg since this museum has opened and I just got to visit a few weeks ago. It was a fantastic experience. My favourite part was the holocaust exhibit. they had replications of some artefacts and sad- but eye opening stories. Learned alot and I suggest everyone go visit while they are in Winnipeg.Every 1st Wednesday of...
Plan to visit again and again , with families and with friends.Excellent helps by the guides and every one at the door, tickets staff and the elevator operator.

The Museum is an absolutely beautiful place to visit. It is also a lot to take in. Make sure you afford yourself 3-5 hours if you want to get the most out of your visit. Definitely have a camera with you. Also make sure you go to the market at The Forks while you are there!
Beautiful building. Easy to walk around. Lots to look at and read. Big store to shopfor souvenirs. Coat check. Restaurant available.

A must see place to visit in Winnipeg. The building itself is unique and should be one of the top ten places in the world to visit. The exhibits gave me unique insights into the history of human rights in Canada. Don't miss it!!!

Took my mother there ; a wonderful person at 87 used a walker and was determined to go to the top and make her way down the walkways.. She was so impressed and made me realize how lucky we are here in Winnipeg to have such a wonderful place to visit and realize our past and future!

Unique and one of a kind building for a one of a kind museum. Interactive displays that draw you into Human Rights. I took out of town friends to the Museum and they were quite pleasantly surprised that Winnipeg offered this kind of Museum.
The building is very unique and one of a kind. Absolutely beautiful view of the city also!Excellent and extremely educational displays throughout every floor of the building.A must to see!
Very interesting and sad at times to see what some peoples have had to endure. Hopefully this museum can help us see people and situations differently and learn from our past.
We took our friends visiting from Halifax. The museum covers all Canadian people and quite politically correct. A good visit and informative.

If you like elementary school type models and pictures expositions, this will be up your alley.The whole time you will be thinking "what a missed opportunity to actually use this space for something worthwhile, like a better science museum, for example".Lots of space unutilized because, really, they have not a whole lot to show!Waste of tax money....

This remarkable architectural marvel houses a truly one of a kind experiential confrontation with the good and evil aspects of the human journey and your time here will definitely change the way you contemplate what every person should be entitled to as a basic bill of rights. In a sophisticated , yet intuitive layout , you are exposed to the...
Amazing building with so many interactive displays. Very informative and brings so many issues to the forefront.

Finally Winnipeg has a world class attraction. I'm not saying that Winnipeg is not worth a visit. It is. There are lots of cool things to see and do but this museum puts Winnipeg on the map. It is in my opinion an architectural masterpiece and for that reason worth visiting alone. This museum is not one rich in artifacts...

I live in Ottawa and was in Winnipeg on business. With a few hours to spare we decided to go to the museum. Download the app beforehand so you can review the exhibits and see the layout (esp if you are pressed for time). This way you can go to your preferred exhibits. If you don't take the elevator there...

All the interesting stuff is on the first three floors. A lot of walking. Beautiful building with unique use of materials. The displays are sure to satisfy every visitor no matter how challenged. Still, I have more visits planned to really get the depth of each display. The ameneties like gift shop and food service are also enjoyable.

Lots of walking and hard on the legs. Take plenty of kleenex. as emotional experiences vary wildly. Excellent presentation methods and understand touring exhibits will vary throughout the year. Wouldn't take young children, say under 10!
The actual design of this building is worth checking out. It was a lot of reading and walking... not sure I would go again. Loved the elevator to the top though!

The first thing that struck us as amazing was certainly the architectural marvel that is the museum itself! It's truly quite beautiful with an interesting shape and an equally as interesting interior! The first hall would have to be my favourite, ethereal, quite and so large it really brought me into a place of my thoughts I'd never been! If...

The Garden of Contemplation is the perfect place to get a feel for the architecture before seeing the exhibits. You can't see everything in one day, so plan to come back or spend 8 hours and eat there. It is an eye-opener, very informative and very often very sad, but you need to know these things and I found inspiration...

The message at the entrance is that we all have a story. The Museum represents us humans as interconnected. My group was amazed that these stories are being told--that there isn't government censorship to human right violations. Human perception has rapidly changed over the years of what is considered a violation. The Museum helps us to hit the reset button...
The museum displays spectacular architecture and the guides provide an excellent overview of the exhibits to allow you to go back for a more detailed tour.
If you love architecture or would like to learn more about Human Rights. Go see this museum! So much to see. You might have to go a couple times to see it all! Must see when visiting Winnipeg.

I had a fantastic experience at the Human Rights Museum. I was on a tour during an engineering conference so the tour guide focused on the architectural aspects of the building a lot, and it is absolutely fascinating.The exhibits I was able to see were interesting as well, and there is so much content I would love to come...

First off, the building is amazing. Secondly, the collection is unparalleled, everything from the uniform Malala was wearing when she was shot to General Daulaire's flak vest worn in Rwanda. Lots of interactives and videos make this an all day activity. Finally the gift shop and cafe are both worth a visit so leave time.

The museum itself is very interesting. The staff is always willing to answer questions and to explain exhibits. Would go again (the Ramps are a fun workout to walk up). There's also a great view at the very top of the tower!
We visited with out of town relatives and they were very impressed by the professional displays throughout the museum.

This is definitely a destination attraction in Winnipeg, or for that matter, a necessity for anyone traveling in or around the area. I would suggest that it be the destination. Outside of the architecture (which is phenomenal by itself) the museum is extremely well laid out and interesting. Many,many interactive displays, all very well done. As you rise in the...

During a visit to Winnipeg by my spouse's cousins, we took the opportunity to finally visit the Museum. We were fortunate to visit on a day of a special promotion. This Museum is built in a very beautiful structure and has some excellent content. It is a good combination of visual and listening. There are several movies explains the plights of various people's with a whole floor dedicated to Aboriginal people and another to atrocities from around the world. You can easily spend 3-4 hours if not more here and...
Make sure you allot yourself enough time to appreciate the museum- at least 3 hours minimum.. Depending on you time, ask the staff their recommendation for your visit.

Could have read a book rather than go here. A lot of walking up rampos, unique architecture (over priced to build) but poor displays auness you like to read a lot. Will buy a book next time.Entry fee too high unless you are aboriginal, go figure, human rights?

The architecture of the building is beautiful, especially the contemplation ponds.The exhibits are a reminder of the history of human rights around the world.We will return again as it is a lot to take in in one visit.
Great museum! Will go again soon. Very enlightening. Found the various artifacts intriguing along with the narration.

I came to this attractions simply for my friend visiting from NB who had heard great things about the museum.I figured it would be boring and uninteresting but was I ever wrong! The architecture alone was breathtaking and all the information and knowledge is impressive. The view from the very top floor observation deck is definitely the best part....

I enjoyed this museum with two adult children.While visiting the museum the top floor was an exhibit of Women's Issues. We went to the museum with our two sons, aged 13 and 17. We really enjoyed it. It is a beautiful building to see, inside and out. The exhibits are interesting, motivating and very educational. The gift store has lots of unique items. Everyone should visit at least once!

14 of us met to eat lunch and take a guided tour. The food in the restaurant was very tasty! The service was good. Sure it's a fancy looking building on the outside but the displays inside are very lac-lustre. Having been to the holocaust museum in Washington and some of the other smithsonians around there, there is really no comparison. Plus, if ur elderly or have issues with mobility there is a ton of walking inside the building. Won't be going again..:(
Please dont make me go here again. It was exhausting. Not worth the money to see the building even. The upstairs pond area was neat but also not worth it. I couldn't wait to leave.
Beautiful building, both inside and exterior. Find significant history there and many stories related to one's Family.

Just awful. So many other things that money could've been spent on. The entire museum can be fit into the first floor. Native Americans get free entry, which doesn't seem very "human rights" to me. Great architecture, but that's all this place has going for it. Save your time and money.

Had a social evening here during the conference and the whole place was open to explore. Many neat exhibits that were not just words on a board, lots of visuals and interaction. Very engaging experience in a museum. Beautiful ramps that have amazing lighting, made for nice photos. View from the top was spectacular.

This is an amazing museum and piece of architecture! I went on a 60 minute tour over the Christmas break (usually 90 minutes but shortened, I guess, due to the number of people coming through). It was a great overview of the museum and the galleries. Great way to start but so much more to see as the tour is...

The structure is impressive. The exhibits are striking. The contents of the exhibits are historical but slanted politically. Some of the exhibits are not as historically accurate for political reasons as would be desirable.

The shape and design of the building is phenomenal.. I was there for a Christmas party but we had the ability to wonder through the museum and learn so much about how people were mistreated.. and some of which wasn't all that long ago! Enjoyed the visit!
Brought my camera and captures some great shots within the museum. Great museum. great location close to the forks.

I went for a 2hr visit with my girls be sure to wear comfy shoes. It's a beautiful building with very informative information. I especially enjoyed the short videos on the migrant workers. Be sure to take the elevator to the very top of the pinnacle for a breathe taking view of downtown Winnipeg
Quite uplifting. No need to worry about it being depressing - serious topics done very well. Plus beautiful building inside and out.

It is National museum calibre. It will probably take many visits to truly absorb all this museum has to offer but the first visit is stunning. The architecture is an exhibit of its own with deep thoughtful meaning. I learned so much about Canada and our struggle in regards to Human Rights.

I was so excited to visit the museum and then I didn't want to leave. The building is beautiful and the message is poignant. you could spend days in order to see everything but in an hour and a half visit I was Content that I had captured the essence of its meaning and significance. But I am keenly interEsted...
Anyone visiting Winnipeg are sure to be truly impressed with both the architechure and the content. An unbelievable experience!

It's a very interactive musuem with many different type of expositions/subjects. My girlfriend who hates musuem would of stay there the full day. Expect minimum 3-4 jours if you want to see most of the rooms. You won't get bored, a must do in Winnipeg!

This was such an amazing opportunity and I'll start by saying that we went on the free night (first Wednesday evening of the month).The museum is beautiful and there are so many things to learn about; I was blown away in so many ways. It did not feel like we were in Winnipeg because of how perfect and beautiful...

Pleasant visit in a beautyful building with a nice view of Winnipeg. However, the museum is short on content. They must have spent a fortune to build this place with an incredible amount of lost space.

Once of the best museums I have ever been too (and I have been to many). If only I had had a full day to spend here exploring, listening, interacting, learning, and most importantly....reflecting. A visit (virtual or real) to this museum should be on every Canadian school curriculum. This museum is a reason to return to Winnipeg.Oh, not...

To me, people who chant about human rights tend to be a little out there politically, but the focus of the museum was on real human rights, like freedom and expression. Spread over a few floors, give yourself minimum half a day otherwise you might be a bit rushed. Great location too for a whole day trip.
Subject matter is dark as the very harsh side of history is explored but the staffing, architecture and presentation is wonderful

Most amazing museum I have visited in Winnipeg. Was by far better than my expectations as well as those who were with me. Spent a little over three hours and finished with a view from the tower. Worth every penny.

Less a "museum" and more a giant info booth with crazy amounts of wasted dead space. We saw the magna carta on display at the time which was cool but honestly having to pay extra to see that and the quite pricey entrance fee and very very few artifacts it's not something I would visit again.

You must check this out not your usual museum this one has a lot of history plus the architectural appeal is quite fascinating built with lots of glass & white translucent marble it's absolutely beautiful plus just a short walk away from the forks of the river!
Very interesting with VERY striking architecture. Really too much to see in one visit, and some of it was quite depressing, although thought provoking. Good views from the tower.

The architecture is incredible. Walking along the lit up alabaster (a healing stone) walkways feels like a healing journey. Although one tries to take photos, it's just too big to actually show how magnificent this place really it. The content can seem overwhelming, but the beauty of the structure allows a peaceful reflection and a feeling of inspiration and hope....

We took the guided general tour for the whole museum. It's a quick way to get a full overview of this national beauty. That tour permits you to know where to focus for more detailed visiting. This tour will give you a fantastic taste of all it's displays and information. Beautiful building! Restaurant is good and quick.

The building is a huge eye sore, not sure what is so special about it other than the $350 mil cost. For that money, we could build 10 museums, and at least renovate the one we already have that is in NEED of renovation. Also, if it's about human rights, make it a precedent by making admission FREE, or at...

Unfortunately this is one of the best kept secrets in the City of Winnipeg. Most people you talk to have never been there and it is a shame. It is Centrally located and has ample parking. The design and architecture of the building is worth the admission charge alone. The displays are articulate, informative and very well displayed. Numerous displayed...

If you ever visit Winnipeg please budget at least half a day to visit this museum. Easily one of the most stunning architecture in the city, it is also one of the only museums specifically dedicated to featuring human rights issues in Canada, and the only national museum outside Ottawa.After decades of planning, the museum was only opened in...

A beautiful museum with superior displays of Human Rights Issues. Of course, there will be more to do but it is an excellent start and I love how the museum upgrades displays regularly. Excellent for a new museum.

We took our 10 year old grandson one afternoon not knowing what to expect. I don't think he got much out of it but was a good sport as we walked through. I would like to go back again and take the tour. It is a very senior friendly facility and senior rate was very affordable.
very worthwhile and informative. we had lunch in the restaurant, but i'd go earlier next time and then walk over to the Forks for lunch.
Amazing architecture and so much to see and learn inside. Requires more than one visit. Can't wait to go back again and again.

I recommend first time visitors take the guided tour. A visitor guide is available for those who prefer to explore on their own. On Saturday and Sunday there is free parking right across from the entrance.Firstly the building itself is worth the visit.From the outside with its imposing structure to the architecture throughout the inside it is truly remarkable...

The exhibits are so rich that you probably need several visits to absorb it all. It's almost a blessing that not all the exhibits are successful, because then you'd have even more to try to take in! Don't worry if something doesn't click for you; the next thing will keep you absorbed for a long time.And it's not a...

CMHR has been criticised for its poor treatment of FN issues. I still find this to be the case. The museum experience is like visiting a student 'science fair' with displays on various human rights topics in Canada.

Was a very well laid out museum. The best part was the lookout up top. Great topics to read up on, beautiful walkways. Lovely water area that is relaxing. Downside is the parking, we went on a long weekend, hard to park.

This is must go to place for everyone. There is wheelchair access for those who require and food if in case you get hungry. A great place to bring kids to edcuate them on not only in history, but what thr future holds if we forget abkut our mistakes
This is just one of the great attractions that make Winnipeg a must visit destination . The architecture is very similar to the Guggenheim in Bilbao
A world-class architectural design but more importantly a world-class message. This museum is an eye-opener as well as a interesting combination of human rights issues. Very interactive

Great experience. I feel like you can visit this museum 10-15 times and not run out of exhibits to see/information to read. 100% worth each and every visit. Educational but also interactive - and you definitely get your steps in!

I was very interested to see what the new museum would entail and it was at the top of my list for my last visit to Winnipeg. I found the use of technology exceptional - in particular, the accessibility that it brought to the exhibits. There were also very friendly volunteers on hand. I did question some of the Canadian...

Thought provoking, moving and emotional. The building itself is worth the visit; intriguing architecture and beautiful spaces. Staff, and there are lots of them, are friendly and helpful. Informative exhibits that cause reflection. It would take days to go through in detail but even if you have a couple hours it is well worth the time to visit.

The Canadian Museum for Human Rights is the newest museum operated by the government of Canada. It opened officially in 2014. It has had a somewhat controversial history and has been funded by a substantial amount of private money.The Museum building is an imposing structure in the Forks area of Winnipeg, not far from the core part of downtown....
Very well done - an excellent resource to learn about HR in a Canadian and world wide context. The Canadian floor is truly exceptional.

If you're visiting Winnipeg, reserve several hours to visit the Museum of Human Rights. The museum is exceptionally well done and informative. It has a wonderful mix of artifacts, history, and interactive activities. The tower has stunning views. This is a must-do in Winnipeg.

Plan for a good two and a half hours, even three plus if you want to visit the gift shop, which you should. I expected this museum to be really depressing and it was the opposite, it was really inspiring. The exhibits showed so many examples of how people have overcome discrimination and exclusion it was hard to not feel...

I spent 3 hours at the museum with a group of grade 12 students in town for a Debate Competion, not enough time. The 17 year olds with us enjoyed the experience and the majority I talked with said they wanted more time.This makes Winnipeg worth a layover on a trip across Canada.i am planning two full days !

If I could manage it I would have every Canadian see this museum. From the standpoint of the historic message, the connections on human rights, as an architectural marvel, the application of technologies or just because ...... I'd recommend spending a few hours at this site.It will change your way of looking at the world and your perception of...

People told about the museum but I thought there would be little to it apart from the modern outside architecture. It turned out be a marvel inside as well, both architecturally and in content. The museum takes you through the evolution of human rights through time from antiquity to modern times, highligths the progress and setbacks in a masterful array...

This museum is one of my favourites in Canada--the experience was incredibly interactive and engaging.
